column2: Awaken to the New Year Retreat

An online New Year’s retreat taught by Luang Por Pasanno from January 1 to January 3, 2021 (Malaysian time) organized by the Buddhadhamma Foundation and Bandar Utama Buddhist Society. 350 people in 19 countries participated.

Text
++Sutta++: SN 47.3: Purify the foundations of wholesomeness.

I find it very difficult to stay with the breath. After 15-20 minutes, the mind will be very bored with the breath and cannot stay with it. Could you advise what is a good meditation for an easily restless mind?
MN 118: Ānāpānasati Sutta
AN 11.1, AN 11.12, and SN 55.40 illustrate the causal chain between happiness and samādhi.
The mind is scattered and wandering. Any advice to settle down the mind? I'm currently practicing Buddho.
The [previous question](excerpt:Awaken2021_S1_F1) answers this in detail.
Is it all right to do Buddho recitation after my mind is calm on breath meditation?
How to overcome anxiety? How always to be with Dhamma in the heart?
How to get rid of judgemental critical thoughts about others?
When we meditate, we observe our breath. What should we do if we reach a state of stillness where no breath can be observed?

During my sitting this morning, the thoughts keep arising one after the other. It seems endlessly. How do I notice, learn, and recognize thoughts as a function of the mind and not be affected by them? Also, how can one make use of skillful thoughts in meditation?
_Kae nun lae_ (Thai) – It's just that much.|Ajahn Chah
What technique helps one see arising and ceasing really clearly?
What technique to use to realize the fruits of this practice in this life? What technique is easiest and most effective?
I can guarantee that looking for the easiest way is the least effective way.
Practice is one mistake after another.|Dōgen
Someone asks the Dalai Lama, "What is the easiest and quickest way to realize emptiness?" The Dalai Lama cries.
AN 3.137: A teaching of effort.

In regard to compassion practice, I feel as if I have refined the awareness of myself and how my actions impact others. Also, my sensitivity has increased. If I feel that I have said or done something that caused someone hurt, I immediately attempt to clean it up. At the same time, I feel great pain for having been unskillful. Please advise on how to refine my understanding so that I suffer less for this.
When we accidentally break the Eight Precepts, once we realize it, what's the proper response in the mind?
about the function of mindfulness of breathing.

Regarding metta practice, sometimes metta is there and it helps to handle challenging situations. But sometimes there is restlessness and hostility, and I get reactive. How to work with this so the mind can be tamed?
Sometimes in meditation, it feels like I'm moving in waves even though my body is still. What does it mean? What should I do when it happens?
MN 10.4: Satipaṭṭhāna Sutta.
I would appreciate further explanation of vitakka and vicāra.
Ajahn Chah's teachings about vitakka-vicāra.
What are excercises for laypeople to overcome laziness?
There is a constant sense of confusion underneath most of the experiences. Other defilements come and go, but moha of various form and intensity seems to be always present. Any suggestions?
The mind is a liar and a cheat.|Ajahn Chah
Can you please speak to the difference in beginning metta meditation with self as opposed to beginning with an external object or person? I often feel depleted when directing outwards.
Chanting Book p. 41: "May I abide in well-being."
How does one live in harmony with others who hold different views and have different understanding about things? How does one live in harmony with oneself when facing challenges?

Let the forest teach you. If you look around in the forest, there's big trees, there's little trees, there's straight trees, there's crooked trees, there's vines. They all live together in harmony.|Ajahn Chah
Chanting Book p. 46, Maṅgala Sutta: Don't associate with fools.
"What is the essence of the Buddha's teachings?"  — "Is this a big piece of wood or a little piece of wood?"|Ajahn Chah
